Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2012 08:29AM SaraT wrote: Spinnerpom, Thank you for the explanation and clarification of external radiation. It was VERY educational. I have just completed 7 of 29 treatments and after the second treatment I could already feel some pain in the area. The area that seems to be sensitive to the radiation is under my right arm in the area where I lost a lot of lymph nodes during surgery. I get treated in three different places. The first treatment goes for about a minute and I can feel it (although I thought I imagined it). I am surprised because everything I read and was told, I probably would not have any reaction or side effects until around the 5th week. Now I am wondering what kind of pain and damage I'm in for after only 7 treatments! Thanks again for the education. I have a few questions for my oncologist on Wednesday.
Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2014 10:32AM SaraT wrote: I realize these posts are older, but I am experiencing this phenomenon myself.  I am two years out of chemo treatment.  I seem to be tanning very easily with lots of freckles.  I just got back from the Jersey shore and have a nice tan.  I was very diligent in applying 30+ sunscreen.  No burn (first time) and a nice tan.  I have NEVER tanned in my life!  As a teen, I tried, believe me.  I thought the melanin in your skin you had was all you got.  I didn't know it was possible to tan if you had low amounts of melanin.  I go to my onc next month and will discuss.
Posts.Title: Chemo tan bhd1 jnh
